Between 1581 and 1728, a 147‐ year period in which pandemic influenza seemingly disappeared,
5 countless local and regional influenza outbreaks were documented in Europe, the New World, and elsewhere. During this time, a close temporal–geographic association between equine and human influenza‐like disease activity began to be documented in hundreds of medical, epidemiologic, and other publications. The first well‐documented occurrence in the Renaissance followed a modest 1647–1648 human outbreak at the end of the Thirty Years’ War in Spain, in French soldiers in Germany, and in their cavalry horses.
